I dont like Starbucks, never really have. But its an interesting thought exercise If you were given 85 million signing bonus plus an even sicker compensation package, what changes would you make to prove you were worth it? Myself, my forte is in making services and products undeniably great, and letting quality drive the business side. Not to the exclusion of shrewd business strategy and tactics, but I just put the priority on having something great that people want, and letting that be the flywheel. So for me, Id finally accept the incredibly common perception that Starbucks actual coffee is mediorceburnt. Weve seen others publicly and with humility accept and fix that... see McCafe, DPZ, CMG, etc. For those who say you cant make that change! I say you cant expect big changes unless you make changes. For those who say the old is good enough, I point to the stock performance as proof its not. Id be the best quality and go with a nicer but more broadly appealing taste profile. As SBUX, wed have the scale and resources to get the very best while still benefitting from scale. Im not sweating about margins in the first wave of this transformation because frankly a drink that you can charge a food price for suggests margin not be a problem over time. Second Id embrace some tech. People are kind of over the myth that you need a slow paced barista teasing out your drink for five minutes. CafeLux and Nespresso have shown you can get 90 of great coffee or cold drinks without lifting a finger. Id seek to take the best of learnings from those and apply them to a faster service model. Maybe that means the barista role is to focus on the part only they can do, and do best, but spares them from the other 90. Thats still TBD, but the goal of pumping out the actual drinks, cold or hot, WAY faster is not negotiable. In parallel wed have some kind of highly mediamentionable value choices. Perhaps not the 99 cent coffee that every pundit thinks they were the first to think of, since it would only be reinforcing the oldbad taste and also trading short term traffic surge which isnt the problem for weaker reputation and perception. But maybe some quick and easy 3 buck options that are enough to generate broad public knowledge. The taste and speed have to be newsworthy upgrades. The value options must also generate a buzz, but should be aligned with supporting not undermining the first two priorities. There would be more phases, but the emergency mission would be whole new supply and taste, combined with huge efficiency boost by automating that which can be. That phase alone probably justifies yesterdays 20 billion move.

If the company viewed the other leaders within the company as equally competent to lead the company as the CEO, but cheaper, they wouldve simply hired those leaders instead. This will be updated after Q3 10-Q on Nov. 7th. Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 (justified if Ouster proves the delayed sale and new sales growth are locked in).As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Now divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Now factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue (Edit: over 30 times more revenue based on recent MVIS earnings warning for Q3).TTM P/S 7 Fair Value mark of $14.42 is a valuation mark, a starting point, and recent trading history shows that this is also a price range that OUST has traded into on good news. If you wanted to be even more conservative in your Fair Value analysis, you could use TTM P/S 5 that puts a more conservative mark at $10.30 but that is still above the current OUST trading range.

I have a few questions about the Ouster OS series technology vs the coming DF technology.It seems the differentiators for the OS series are: 1) VCSEL laser emitter. 2) Optics which define the focal length of the target.3) SPAD photon detector.4) Micro-optical system. (not exactly sure what this means other than processing fpga/uP/etc..)The information that I can find on the DF sensor basically is the same as above, but significantly includes two other items:5) Global Shutter.6) Digital Flash.I do not have experience with Lidar, but I do know something about camera design and RTL logic design in FPGA's.  Global shutter (as opposed to a rolling shutter) means all the pixels are exposed to the image (the light) at the same time.  This is why they don't have motion artifacts and yes, it's a big deal.  Digital Flash would burst broadcast VCSEL laser emitters simultaneously, which you can see would work well with a Global shutter.  So I have two basic questions and I'm not even sure if anyone will know, but please shout out if you do.1) All of the OS series device datasheets have a specification for "Rotation Rate" in the range of 10 or 20 Hz.    What is this talking about?  2) Are the differences between the OS and DF series of devices summed up in the Global Shutter and Digital Flash capabilities or am I missing an important item?Lastly, question #2 is not meant to say "That's not enough"..  actually that's a huge deal, but I am still curious for the answer.thanks,david

FYI, OUST's Relative Strength Index (RSI) went to 78 a couple hours ago. Not the only Oscillator to check up on, but there will be some profit-taking along the way. Day-traders will make their buck and move on, but good things come to those who wait. For those who don't know - when RSI goes over 80, it's normally considered "Over-Bought" territory as if moving up too much, too fast. Some stocks can overcome the data when in extremes (many Meme Stocks do it all the time) but the day traders who look for stocks over RSI of 80 normally start to short the stock.

This may have already been commented on below, but I just saw a comparison of the Ouster 3.0 vs. 3.1 firmware.  The takeaway is that the 3.1 firmware has the capacity to separate very nearfield masses from others.  This in turn gives them the ability to filter out obstructions on the glass of the sensor.  I expect there is some pretty decent math going on behind this in that they still have the full image, without the artifacts of the obstructions on the glass.  The demo is a live image as the camera is being sprayed with a water bottle.  The new firmware image does not seem to change at all.  Well worth looking at..  and obviously a very strong selling point to many of their potential customers.

My criticism of Tesla is well-known to some of you, and not just because Tesla is a competitor of Ouster, as Tesla's FSD with Optical Sensors competes against Ouster and LiDAR companies. Today's news reemphasized other issues with Tesla that I haven't voiced much here, but you should consider the growing list:GEICO denied/cancelled policies for Tesla Cybertruck, as the liability/risks are too lengthy and more being added as inspections and wear reveal significant design flaws.Cybertruck design added aluminum components in areas where Vertical Loads are significant for towing trailers, which means a Cybertruck could rip itself apart if it has a max Gross Weight trailer load, and now the 3rd party engineers looking at this flaw are saying that Cybertruck may need to be reduced to very light trailers that only put around 100 pounds on the tongue. No doubt - Cybertruck's electric motors have plenty of torque to pull heavy loads, but those heavy loads still put weight vertically on the tongue and hitch, which means Tesla engineers obviously haven't worked with trailers and truck suspensions much at all in their careers.Tesla Optical sensors degrade over time, with clouding much like headlamp covers, leading to degradation of photons passively received. This is like having an elderly person with cataracts as the autopilot. Bad eyes, no matter how good Dojo is.Chinese dependency for batteries and vehicle production long term. Elon doesn't prioritize Western production long term.

To Puck: Ouster is far ahead of Tesla for fully autonomous platforms and certifications. Tesla does hold a market leading ADAS product in FSD, but that doesn't mean it's safe, and ADAS is not Full Autonomy. Sales vs accident rates aren't looking good for ADAS FSD, and will get worse as Tesla Robotaxi will also be problematic on the roadway. You gotta start doing more homework instead of spamming to understand the stratification of Autonomy levels vs ADAS. You should know this as a HSAI investor, unless you're merely trading HSAI to make a buck, but with all your "love of China" seeping into your posts, I would have thought you'd be proud of HSAI also being ahead of TSLA for Autonomy certifications (courtesy of Ouster's tech, of course).Tesla has been a customer of both Luminar and Ouster to try and "calibrate" the optical sensors for Tesla to perform more toward the full capabilities of electro-optical LiDAR sensors. It's Elon's hope that he can manage to keep paying very little for cheap optical sensors so he doesn't have to commit the money for more expensive electro-optical sensors. Another flaw is that optical sensors degrade over time with clouding of lenses and/or covers much like headlight covers, whereas active laser pings still get through even when LiDAR covers get old. Elon Musk isn't always right, and he's especially wrong to try and leap into full autonomy with Tesla Robotaxi, unless he gives in and commits to a LiDAR multi-sensor array.

This is actually good news for Ouster, as Tesla's FSD is a direct competitor for Ouster in terms of Auto Industry business for sales of sensors and software.'Safety Disaster:' Tesla FSD 'Galaxies Away From Being Anywhere Close To Competition,' Says Bearish Analyst, As He Assigns Zero Valuation To The Tech

Nearly 14 months ago, I first brought up a policy issue that essentially puts government into the business of subsidizing robotization while disincentivizing hiring actual human workers. Case in point has been the California Minimum Wage shift that has elevated to $20/hour now. What many outside California don't realize, is that Silicon Valley pays a lot of money to lobby State Govt and the Governor to elevate wages, because a costly human is the best incentive to buy robots instead.If you want proof, search for this headline:Chipotle Starts Replacing Workers With Robots to Bypass Californias Minimum Wage LawsThere are at least a dozen articles out for this specific issue, and many other companies are going the same route. In the past, at lower Minimum Wage Levels, the cost of buying robots to work in fast food was prohibitive, but not now. Just be aware that Silicon Valley lobbies your own State Governments also (and Governors) to raise Minimum Wage across the entire USA (and this effort is going global).One could argue it's a Chicken vs Egg debate, but in Silicon Valley, the Golden Goose comes from government, to essentially push out low-wage workers while their tech companies get enriched with automation investments and purchases. I'm a huge supporter of what Ouster is doing for Autonomy, but this is one area where California has laid a rotten egg.

How is Ouster different than their peers? Ouster pursued all the Verticals or sectors outside of the Auto Industry primarily, in ramping up sensor development and with their R&D focus over the years. Ouster applied most resources toward what is now the OS Family of Sensors - not Auto OEM grade/sized, but more of a universal option to put LiDAR on as many different platforms as possible. The OS Family is in the Auto Industry, as post-OEM mods such as panel vans, buses, and semi-trucks.The OS Family opened up a wider variety of Use Cases for customers to develop next-gen solutions, and is why Ouster now has hundreds of customers that have experimented with the OS Family.Amazon uses this same approach, and helps explain why Ouster gets great Margins for their sales (up in the 40% Gross Margin range), because Amazon uses Proteus robots in the warehouse to offset personnel costs. In any business, normally the largest cost driver are the personnel costs. This affects the Cost Of Goods Sold (COGS, an acronym to remember). Amazon will gladly pay a premium for an Ouster sensor, to reduce personnel costs. Whereas a fickle Retail Consumer shopping for an Automobile, may not want to use their limited funds to buy an expensive LiDAR add-on option. In addition, the Auto Industry itself is fickle as to what vendors they buy car parts from (just check how your car stereo speakers change year after year, as one example).Ouster is succeeding because it helps lower COGS in multiple industries.

I find it interesting that Robosense trading in Hong Kong last night (our time) closed up 11% in the face of the news of the US Govt putting restrictions on LiDAR sales for specific areas. My take - Robosense investors/institutions backing them, think they're ok since they aren't primarily in Smart Infrastructure for their LiDAR sensor sales. Hesai is mysteriously up today also, in the face of the news, although only 1/4 normal volume.What the Chinese Investors/backers of Robosense and Hesai may not realize, is that this is merely the first of many legislative actions put toward Chinese LiDAR, and more restrictions are still being crafted in DC that will ultimately deny any/all Chinese produced LiDAR from US sales (possibly all Western nations as well). It's just the "first shot across the bough" and many more volleys will be fired in the future. Are we at war with China? No, not yet, but we are starting to see our Federal Congress/Legislature start to act like we need to have more preparedness in the face of possible future wars.

Here's a small gold nugget found on Ouster's website. If you hadn't read the complete news release before, see the article titled "How 3D lidar is propelling yard and dock logistics towards safer, more efficient operations" but here's a caveat that may not jump out at you initially.ITK Engineering in Germany is behind this development and sales, where Ouster sensors are part of their packaged deals. Ouster's Gemini software also gets packaged into the deal.Why ITK Engineering in itself is the gold nugget - it's a fully-owned subsidiary of Bosch. Why that matters - Bosch made a conscious decision a year ago, to discontinue in-house development of LiDAR sensors. Remember that news? At the time, it was hinted at that Ouster could get Bosch's business for Auto OEM sales, but that's a follow-on discussion at this point. The bigger story is that ITK Engineering is a major artery for sales into European industry, in many forms, and that means Ouster has a going relationship with a major Component manufacturer that has chosen their product AND software for ongoing development.Don't underwhelm this news, when you put 1+1 together - what are the implications for Bosch developing Auto OEM components, once Ouster's DF Sensor is market-ready? And DF Sensor could become a new subcomponent in ITK Engineering's industrial build-outs, aside from OS Family retaining status there as well. We got Bosch. Will Bosch buy OUST?

The growth is there on the OS (360) sensors alone... But I can't wait for the Digital Flash lidar for ADAS as I believe it will be a gamechanger. The Chronos chip is taped out now, so the product launch is getting nearer. CES is only four months away...

A bit of a gift from China - breaking news from Tesla that they are delaying the rollout of Full-Service Driving to both China and Europe, with the reported reasons from China due to Safety concerns based on Tesla's accident record and data security, and in contrast to existing available technology on Chinese vehicles. Translated - FSD's optical sensors are inferior and less safe than LiDAR equipped vehicles. Too bad that plain language doesn't hit the news, as the general public needs to learn the tech differences in Optical vs Electro-Optical sensors - especially if they will risk their lives on the road by taking their hands off the steering wheel and letting the car drive itself. Although there's a tinge of political opposition due to Elon Musk, it's also about the risks of allowing an unproven technology to literally "run free" on public roadways. Sadly, we will see more accidents and deaths due to Tesla FSD, that will become better than paid advertisements for LiDAR.

Interesting article in Fortune magazine (online) about the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), as the Federal Reserve's leadership and board of Governors are all shifting toward Rate Cuts now, but what is hinted at is that there will be a compromise to not achieve 2% inflation to start the cuts. Another source says a Fed Reserve insider has warned that they may face data that signals "Recession' and then blame would be aimed at the Fed for acting too slowly - with a hint that we could see a Rate Cut triggered to as deep as 1 Basis Point (1%). What I take from reading this and other recent Fed related articles - we are about to see history repeat itself from the Carter-to-Reagan economic shift period, where the Fed would do rapid cuts and even increases as the economy gyrated, with cuts being 1% moves and not just the small 1/4% ones we've become more accustomed to in the modern day. Regardless, if Data signals "Recession'" then all bets are off, because if we start seeing Recession in the news going into Election Day, things could go crazy. Anyone want a repeat of 2008-9 crisis?

Stock Buybacks 101, and why they are done:Reduces Dilution of the stock. This is especially true if the company had a long period of using stock-based compensation in formative years and moving toward profitability there is enough cash to buy them back. Same is true for countering the dilution of prior equity offers or ATM sales of shares.Increases the Earnings-per-share metrics. Fewer Shares Outstanding means EPS calculations become more favorable for quarterly and annual reports, influencing stock analysts who center on the EPS performance.A way to return capital to shareholders, with limited taxation. Often an overlooked aspect of stock buybacks, but shareholders that experience an increased share price are not yet taxed, whereas if the company paid a dividend instead, that would have been taxed.The company finds their stock undervalued. Management knows if the company will meet expectations, yet if the stock price does not reflect either their past performance metrics (P/S and/or P/E), and is not fairly valued for known future performance (PEG), a company would wisely buy back its own shares in anticipation of meeting or exceeding performance that near-guarantees the company buys back shares at a price lower than what it should trade toward later.

Excellent article in Top Speed re the Volvo EX90.  The article explains how the launch will include the hardware but for the 1st months the car will simply transmit the information gathered by LiDAR and attendant sensors back to Volvo which will then reprogram and update the owner software over the air.  The ADAS will be fully functional in 2025.The software will gather info on aberrant events the driver/car experience, send it to Volvo, who then incorporates them into the reprogrammed software sent back to the owner.  The self-driving will then be integrated/upgraded.This method is opposed to Waymo or Cruise which gather data with their respective taxi services.Great strategy in my book.

As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 for proven annual revenue growth and pre-profitability Growth Company:OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue.If you wanted to be even more conservative in your Fair Value analysis, you could use TTM P/S 5 that puts a more conservative mark at $10.30 but that is still above the current OUST trading range.

As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock is now $14.42, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 for proven annual revenue growth as a pre-profitability Growth Company:OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Now divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Now factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue.TTM P/S 7 Fair Value mark of $14.42 is a valuation starting point, and recent trading history shows that this is also a price range that OUST has traded into on good news.

Just a word of both encouragement yet challenge to all those currently holding OUST Long. What's changed since last Quarter? Things have changed for the better. Although we had the benefit of an Institution-led run-up last Quarter, partly due to timing of Ouster being added back into the Russell 3000 Index, Ouster was also not yet becoming the clear winner in the LiDAR race.  Now? There is real fear out there - of Ouster's competitors, and of the financial Institutions that wrongly guessed as to who would become a successful LiDAR developer and manufacturer. Those Institutions only have themselves to blame - in many cases, they put lower tier Analysts on the task of determining who the best LiDAR companies are, and as often happens, they were fooled by glossy tri-folds and Investor Presentations while the Analyst did not fully understand the Hard Science of the underlying technology - Electro-Optical LiDAR Sensors. These are mostly analysts that in their day job, normally cover Auto Parts companies that make tires and brakes.  Very few "Pick a Stock" firms picked Ouster to emerge the victor. As of August 15, 2024, based on Q2 2024 10-Q data.Fair Value of Ouster (OUST) stock is now $14.42, adjusted to Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Price-to-Sales (P/S) Ratio at a mark of TTM P/S 7.0 for proven annual revenue growth and pre-profitability Growth Company:OUST TTM Revenue: $99,590,000OUST Shares Outstanding: 48,330,000Divide TTM $99.59M by 48.33M SO = Sales per Share of 2.06Now divide current Stock Price $7.77 by Sales per Share 2.06 = P/S Ratio of 3.77 (lower is better for P/S Ratios).Now factor out for P/S 7.0, multiply current stock price ($7.77) times 7.0 = 54.39, then divide by current P/S 3.77 = $14.42Current OUST Fair Value at TTM P/S 7.0 = $14.42 as a baseline (not a Price Target).If OUST were priced equally to peer LiDAR company MVIS priced at P/S 18.43, OUST would be at $37.98 -- that's the price it would take to equalize OUST and MVIS valuations, and yet OUST isn't equal because it has over 11 times more annual revenue.TTM P/S 7 Fair Value mark of $14.42 is a valuation starting point, and recent trading history shows that this is also a price range that OUST has traded into on good news.

In case you're looking for the proof that Ouster is now Debt-Free, the definitive statement was during CFO Weinswig's time to talk numbers in the Earnings Call, when he said per the transcript:"During the second quarter, we received approximately $16 million from ATM sales. In August, consistent with our strategy to improve our capital structure, we utilized $44 million of cash to fully repay the outstanding balance on our revolving credit line."So it was a Q3 AUGUST (this month) transaction, not a Q2 transaction, which explains why you're seeing a Debt line on the Balance Sheet for 43,973 under the June 30, 2024 column.

Who are the people with interests at conflict with Ouster's success? Let's talk about it...Cantor Fitzgerald, who always gets OUST Price Target wrong, and consistently negative in their analyst calls. Cantor over-bought into MVIS a long time ago, essentially placed their bets on MicroVision winning out in LiDAR, and made a big mistake. They have an interest in recouping lost money in MVIS, and have not bought into OUST like they could have, to this point. Citi, who also chose poorly, over-leveraging themselves into LAZR at higher prices, always favoring high Price Targets on LAZR while low-balling Price Targets on OUST. Their analyst covering both LAZR and OUST was in the bottom 20 of over 6,000 analysts for performance. Won't be surprised if he was fired already.GS, who favors INVZ, was a holder of INVZ shares and helped orchestrate their secondary offer, although things may have turned and GS may have sold off all INVZ holdings at this point. GS was never favorable toward OUST and is still on the sidelines for an analyst to cover Ouster. Considering that OUST went public via SPAC, and GS has typically been anti-SPAC, there's that aspect also.Speaking of SPAC, there's a long list of anti-SPAC institutions, some of which have still not bought into OUST, out of "principle" of their own internal rules. Yes, there are some firms that have blacklisted most all SPAC companies, except if that company uses their services for an Equity Offer or Loan.

Why I'm long.First and foremost I'm investing in the proliferation of LiDAR the technology. At this moment one might say we are in the early stage of a possible ubiquitous tech. The use cases are numerous. The potential revenues are enormous.Why Ouster? On researching LiDAR Velodyne stood out at least in part because of the IP. Even though the executive group was in chaos I bought a thousand shares. That was 6/29/22 at $12.19 per share. I continued to research and discovered Ouster. The difference between Ouster and the perceived LiDAR leader Luminar could not be any more stark. The Luminar CEO is a poser in both the literal and figurative sense. A photo op kinda guy. Pacala on the other hand is an engineer and acts like one. Big plus in my book based on the tech being engineer specific. Even the locations ...Silicon Valley vs Florida...point me to Ouster.I don't celebrate Luminar's downfall. It casts a shadow on the tech and the sector. On the plus side it absolutely confirms that the ADAS portion of LiDAR tech is wide open. imho that's all about form factor/cost. As I come back from a summertime hiatus, I find multiple boards filled with delusion and hype when the 10-Q reports show worse-than-expected results, failing companies, failing CEOs - and somehow there are still people who think their best days are ahead of them. Luminar, Innoviz, MicroVision, and now AEye also - those companies are all failing, and the primary problem for all of them is that they lack true leadership. Lots of Opportunists among all those CEOs, as they know how to make a buck through the process of being a Public Company - but in general are not top-tier scientists or engineers. LiDAR is an Electro-Optics technology.  Show me who among them are top-tier experts on Electro-Optics technology. I dare you - look at their track record in Academia and Industry, and who among them actually has a grasp on, and is ahead of their peers for advancing Electro-Optics technology. Who among them is invited to speak at MIT? Or Stanford? And I'm not talking about speaking at the Business/Marketing departments - but the Engineering schools.The fact is, most investors who have been duped - are clueless as to the science behind LiDAR Technology, and just how much of a "Hard Science" this is. You cannot drop out of college or fake it, and hope to advance this technology. You just can't. That's why I dub all these CEOs - the "Clowns of LiDAR."
